text:
left England for an unexpected adventure.  

While in the United States, I met with teachers and writers.  

One meeting was with an executive for a nonprofit educational group.  

As I left his office, he made a passing comment.  

He said, "If you decide to stay in America, join us."  

His comment had a curious force.  

It was not his specific question.  

It was his assumption that I had a choice.  

He said, "If you decide to stay..."  

He saw it as a real option.  

This got me thinking.  

I took the elevator down to the lobby.  

I took a single sheet of paper from someone's desk.  

I sat in the lobby and tried to answer a question.  

The question was, "If you could do only one thing, what would it be?"  

The result was that piece of paper.  

Law school was not written on it.  

I had always known I could choose not to study law.  

But emotionally, it had never been an option.  

I realized that sacrificing my power to choose was a choice.  

It was a bad one.  

By refusing to choose "not law school," I chose law school.  

I did not actually want to be there, but I chose by default.  

I realized that when we surrender our ability to choose,  

something or someone else will choose for us.  

A few weeks later, I officially quit law school.  

I left England and moved to America.  

I started down the path of becoming an author and a teacher.  

You’re reading this now because of that choice.  

This choice impacted my life significantly.  

I value how it changed my view about choices even more.  

We often think of choice as a thing.  

But a choice is not a thing.  

Our options may be things, but a choice is an action.  

It is not just something we have, but something we do.  

This experience led me to a liberating realization.  

We may not always control our options.  

But we always control how we choose among them.  

Have you ever felt stuck without a real choice?  

Have you ever felt stress from holding two contradictory beliefs?  

"I can’t do this" and "I have to do this"?  

Have you ever given up your power to choose bit by bit?

**PAGE SUMMARY:** The author reflects on the importance of actively exercising the power of choice in shaping one's life path.
